workflow.name: Create a dynamic Telegram bot menu system with multi-level navigation
workflow.description:
# ğŸ¤– Telegram Bot with Dynamic Multi-Level Menu System

## What This Workflow Does

Ever wanted to build a Telegram bot with professional-looking menus that actually work? This n8n workflow creates an interactive bot with dynamic inline keyboards, multi-level navigation, and smart button routing - all without writing complex code from scratch.

The bot features a clean separation between your menu structure and business logic. This means you can change your menus anytime without breaking the underlying functionality. Think of it like WordPress menus but for Telegram bots - you define the navigation, and the workflow handles everything else.

Your bot will respond with personalized messages, remember user context, handle button clicks smoothly (no annoying loading spinners!), and route different actions to specialized handlers. Whether users are rating your service, checking their subscription status, or navigating through settings, everything just works.

## ğŸš€ Getting Started in 3 Minutes

### Step 1: Get Your Bot Token
Head over to Telegram and chat with @BotFather. Create a new bot (or use an existing one) and grab that token. In the workflow, find the purple "Set Bot Token" node and replace `[!!! YOUR_BOT_TOKEN_HERE !!!]` with your actual token.

### Step 2: Activate the Magic
Save the workflow, click on "Production" tab, and you'll see a webhook URL. Toggle the workflow to Active. That's it - your bot is live!

### Step 3: See It In Action
Message your bot on Telegram. Type `/start` and watch your beautiful menu appear. Click around, explore the buttons - everything is already set up and working.

## ğŸ¨ Making It Yours

### Want to Add Your Own Menus?
Open the workflow and look for the sticky note titled "ğŸ“– COMPLETE GUIDE: ADDING MENUS & ACTIONS". I've written step-by-step instructions right there in the workflow. You'll find exact examples showing how to add a contact menu, subscription status checker, or whatever you need.

The beauty is in the simplicity - menus are just text and buttons. No complicated logic mixed in. Check the "ğŸ“š REAL EXAMPLES" sticky note for copy-paste templates you can modify.

### Need Custom Actions?
When a button needs to actually DO something (save data, call an API, send an email), that's where handlers come in. The workflow includes 7 pre-built handlers for common tasks like ratings, language switching, and analytics. Want to add your own? The "ğŸ’¡ ADDING HANDLERS" sticky note walks you through it.

## ğŸ’¡ Why This Workflow Is Different

Most Telegram bot tutorials have you mixing menu code with business logic, making changes a nightmare. This workflow separates everything cleanly. Your menus live in one place, your logic in another. It's like having a control panel for your bot.

The workflow also solves a common n8n limitation - the native Telegram node doesn't support dynamic inline keyboards. Instead of giving up, this workflow uses HTTP requests directly to the Telegram API, giving you full control over every feature.

## ğŸ”§ Pro Tips from the Trenches

After building dozens of Telegram bots, here's what I've learned:
- Always include a "Back" button - users panic without an escape route
- Use emojis in your buttons - they make everything friendlier
- Test each menu path after changes - one typo can break navigation
- Keep action handlers focused - one handler, one job

Hit a snag? Check the "ğŸ› TROUBLESHOOTING & TIPS" sticky note in the workflow. I've documented all the common "gotchas" and their fixes.

## ğŸ“¦ What's Included

This workflow comes with everything you need:
- Centralized menu configuration system
- Smart routing that automatically detects which button was pressed
- 7 ready-to-use action handlers (modify or replace as needed)
- Parallel processing for lightning-fast responses
- Built-in error handling with fallback menus
- Comprehensive documentation right in the workflow via sticky notes

## ğŸš€ Taking It Further

Once you're comfortable with the basics, this architecture scales beautifully. Connect a database to remember user preferences. Integrate with your CRM to pull customer data. Add payment processing for a shopping bot. The modular design means you can enhance one part without touching the others.

The workflow sticky notes contain advanced examples for multi-language support, user authentication, and API integrations. Everything is explained in plain English with code examples you can actually use.

## ğŸ¤ One Last Thing

This workflow started as a simple dynamic menu with rating workflow and evolved into something much more powerful through community feedback. If you build something cool with it, I'd love to hear about it. And if you get stuck, remember - all the answers are in those sticky notes. I spent way too much time making them ridiculously detailed so you wouldn't have to struggle like I did.

Happy bot building! ğŸ¯

---

**Version**: 1.0 - Centralized Menu System with Branching
**Author**: Ruslan Elishev

parameters.content: # ğŸ“š REAL EXAMPLES TO COPY ## Example 1: Add a Contact Menu **In Load Menu Config, add:** ```javascript contact: { text: 'ğŸ“ Contact Us\n\nHow can we help?', keyboard: [ [{ text: 'ğŸ“§ Email', callback_data: 'email' }], [{ text: 'ğŸ’¬ Chat', callback_data: 'chat' }], [{ text: 'ğŸ“± Phone', callback_data: 'phone' }], [{ text: 'ğŸ”™ Back', callback_data: 'main' }] ] }, email: { text: 'ğŸ“§ Email: support@example.com', keyboard: [[{ text: 'ğŸ”™ Back', callback_data: 'contact' }]] }, ``` **In Main Menu, add button:** ```javascript { text: 'ğŸ“ Contact', callback_data: 'contact' } ``` --- ## Example 2: Add Subscription Status **Step 1 - Add to actionCommands:** ```javascript 'check_subscription', ``` **Step 2 - In Action Router expression:** ```javascript $json.command === 'check_subscription' ? 6 : ``` **Step 3 - In Default Handler:** ```javascript if (input.command === 'check_subscription') { input.customData = { status: 'Premium User', expires: '30 days' }; } ``` **Step 4 - Menu with placeholder:** ```javascript subscription: { text: 'Status: {status}\nExpires: {expires}', keyboard: [[{ text: 'ğŸ”™', callback_data: 'main' }]] }, ``` --- ## Example 3: Multi-Level Settings ```javascript settings: { text: 'âš™ï¸ Settings', keyboard: [ [{ text: 'ğŸ”” Notifications', callback_data: 'notif_menu' }], [{ text: 'ğŸŒ Language', callback_data: 'lang_menu' }], [{ text: 'ğŸ”™ Main', callback_data: 'main' }] ] }, notif_menu: { text: 'ğŸ”” Notifications', keyboard: [ [{ text: 'âœ… On', callback_data: 'notif_on' }], [{ text: 'âŒ Off', callback_data: 'notif_off' }], [{ text: 'ğŸ”™ Settings', callback_data: 'settings' }] ] }, ``` ## Copy & Modify These! Just change the text and callback_data values

## ğŸ”€ Router Outputs

0. Rating Handler
1. Language Handler
2. Analytics Handler
3. Statistics Handler
4. Feedback Handler
5. Settings Handler
6. Default Handler

Each handler processes its specific commands independently

# ğŸš€ QUICK START GUIDE

## Step 1: Add Your Bot Token
1. Open Telegram and message @BotFather
2. Create a bot with `/newbot` or use existing
3. Copy your bot token
4. Find **'Set Bot Token'** node (purple)
5. Replace `YOUR_BOT_TOKEN_HERE` with your token

## Step 2: Set Webhook
1. After saving workflow, click **'Production'**
2. Copy the webhook URL shown
3. Activate the workflow

## Step 3: Test Your Bot
1. Message your bot on Telegram
2. Try commands: /start, /help
3. Click the interactive buttons

## Troubleshooting:
- **404 Error**: Wrong bot token
- **No response**: Webhook not active
- **Buttons not working**: Check callback_data values

# ğŸ“š WORKFLOW ARCHITECTURE

## SIMPLIFIED DESIGN:
**Separation of Concerns**

### 1ï¸âƒ£ Menu Config (Load Menu Config node)
- ONLY navigation structure
- Text & button definitions
- Multi-level hierarchy support
- NO business logic here!

### 2ï¸âƒ£ Router (Action Router node)
- Detects callback_data
- Routes to handlers (7 outputs)
- Pure switching logic

### 3ï¸âƒ£ Handlers (7 separate nodes)
- ALL business logic
- API calls, database ops
- Dynamic content generation

## DATA FLOW:
1. **Telegram Trigger** â†’ Receives messages
2. **Parallel**: Load Config + Extract Command
3. **Merge** â†’ Combine data
4. **Process** â†’ Find menu & check action
5. **Route** â†’ Send to handler if needed
6. **Build** â†’ Create response
7. **Send** â†’ Back to Telegram

## BENEFITS:
âœ… Easy menu modifications
âœ… Portable configuration
âœ… Clear responsibilities
âœ… Scalable architecture

# ğŸ”§ ADVANCED: CREATE CUSTOM HANDLER

## When You Need a Custom Handler:
When your action needs to:
- Save data to database
- Call external API
- Complex calculations
- Multiple steps

## STEP-BY-STEP:

### Step 1: Copy a Handler
1. Right-click any handler (like 'Default Handler')
2. Click 'Duplicate'
3. Drag the new node to empty space
4. Double-click to rename it

### Step 2: Update Router
1. Double-click **'Action Router'** node
2. Change 'Number of Outputs' from 7 to 8
3. Update the expression:
```javascript
$json.command === 'my_action' ? 7 :
// (7 is your new output number)
```

### Step 3: Connect Your Handler
1. Click the small square on Action Router
2. Drag to your new handler
3. Select output '7' from popup

### Step 4: Write Handler Logic
Double-click your handler and modify:
```javascript
const input = items[0].json;

if (input.command === 'my_action') {
  // Your code here
  const timestamp = new Date();
  
  return [{
    json: {
      ...input,
      customData: {
        result: 'Success!',
        time: timestamp
      }
    }
  }];
}
```

### Step 5: Connect to Response
1. Click small square on your handler
2. Drag to 'Build Response' node
3. Connection complete!

## TEST YOUR HANDLER:
1. Save workflow
2. Test with your bot
3. Check execution to see data flow

# ğŸ“‹ CHECK THE CODE COMMENTS!

The **Load Menu Config** node has detailed inline comments explaining:
- How to add new menus
- Menu structure rules
- Button format
- Navigation patterns
- Multi-level examples

ğŸ‘‰ Open the node and read the comments for complete guidance!

# ğŸ“– COMPLETE GUIDE: ADDING MENUS & ACTIONS ## ğŸ†• PART 1: ADD A SIMPLE MENU **Step 1:** Double-click the **'Load Menu Config'** node **Step 2:** Find this line (around line 200): ``` // DEFAULT FALLBACK - IMPORTANT! ``` **Step 3:** Add your menu BEFORE that line: ```javascript // Your new menu my_menu: { text: 'Welcome to My Menu', keyboard: [ [{ text: 'Option 1', callback_data: 'option1' }], [{ text: 'ğŸ”™ Back', callback_data: 'main' }] ] }, ``` **Step 4:** To make a button go to your menu, find any button and change its callback_data: ```javascript { text: 'ğŸ“ My Menu', callback_data: 'my_menu' } ``` **Step 5:** Click âœ… Save --- ## ğŸ¯ PART 2: ADD AN ACTION BUTTON ### A) Create the Button: **Step 1:** In your menu, add an action button: ```javascript my_menu: { text: 'My Menu', keyboard: [ [{ text: 'âš¡ Do Something', callback_data: 'do_action' }], [{ text: 'ğŸ”™ Back', callback_data: 'main' }] ] }, ``` ### B) Make It Trigger an Action: **Step 2:** Double-click **'Process Command'** node **Step 3:** Find the actionCommands array (line ~10): ```javascript const actionCommands = [ 'rate_1', 'rate_2', // existing items... ``` **Step 4:** Add your action command: ```javascript const actionCommands = [ 'do_action', // â† ADD THIS LINE 'rate_1', 'rate_2', // existing items... ``` ### C) Route to Handler: **Step 5:** Double-click **'Action Router'** node **Step 6:** Find the long expression and ADD at the beginning: ```javascript $json.command === 'do_action' ? 6 : ``` (The number 6 sends it to the Default Handler) ### D) Process the Action: **Step 7:** Double-click **'Default Handler'** node **Step 8:** Add your logic: ```javascript if (input.command === 'do_action') { // What happens when button is clicked input.customData = { message: 'Action completed!' }; } ``` --- ## ğŸ’¡ IMPORTANT TIPS: **Naming Rules:** - Use underscore: `my_menu` âœ… - No spaces: `my menu` âŒ - Keep it simple: `settings` âœ… **Text Formatting:** - `\n` = new line - `Bold` = bold text - Use emojis: ğŸ¯ ğŸ“ âš¡ âœ… **Always Test:** 1. Save workflow 2. Click Execute Workflow 3. Message your bot 4. Click your new button **Common Mistakes:** - Forgot comma after } - Wrong callback_data spelling - Didn't add to actionCommands - Missing back button

# ğŸ› TROUBLESHOOTING & TIPS

## COMMON ISSUES:

**Bot not responding:**
- Workflow must be Active
- Check webhook URL
- Verify bot token

**404 Error:**
- Replace YOUR_BOT_TOKEN_HERE

**Buttons not working:**
- Check callback_data matches
- Verify Answer Callback node

**Menu not found:**
- Falls back to 'default' menu

## PRODUCTION TIPS:

**Security:**
- Use environment variables for token
- Never commit real tokens
- Validate user inputs

**Performance:**
- Add database for persistence
- Cache frequently used data
- Use sub-workflows for complex logic

**Debugging:**
- Use console.log() in code nodes
- Check execution history
- Test with single messages first

user.name: Ruslan Elishev
user.bio: Professional Product Director that cought vibe of Automaion and Solo Programming and Context Aware AI Vibe coding.

data.details: The Function node allows you to execute JavaScript in your workflow. Unlike the Function Item node, this node does not operate on incoming node data per-item. Instead, you must iterate over multiple items of incoming data yourself. This can be useful if you're performing data transformation where you want to manipulate the number of items being outputted by the node (i.e. 1 item is inputted in with nested object, 10 items are outputted without any nested objects)

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
